What is the directional factor for ?: What is the directional factor for ?
How do the direction factor values apply: How do the direction factor values apply ?
What are the directional factor values ?: What are the directional factor values ?
High velocities of wind are observed mor: High velocities of wind are observed more frequently in some sectors directions;
the directional factor allows a reductio: the directional factor allows a reduction when the wind comes from a direction where the probability of occurrence of severe winds is lesser.
« Wind direction » means the direction f: « Wind direction » means the direction from which the wind comes.
By convention, this direction is identif: By convention, this direction is identified by the angle it forms with the North, increasing from 0° to 360° clockwise.
For the calculation of wind actions, onl: For the calculation of wind actions, only a few wind directions are considered;
for example the normal directions to the: for example the normal directions to the facades in the case of buildings.
In the case of buildings, the pressure c: In the case of buildings, the pressure coefficients given in the Section 7 of EN 1991-1-4 take account of this simplification of the procedure;
their values correspond to the most unfa: their values correspond to the most unfavorable direction of a so-called « nominal » angular sector of ±45° around the conventionally considered direction.
Just as the standard requires, in 4.3.2: Just as the standard requires, in 4.3.2 (3), to keep the roughness of the most unfavorable terrain in the nominal angular sector, it is advisable to use the most unfavorable directional factor of the directions contained in this sector.
In other cases, in particular when the c: In other cases, in particular when the construction has been the subject of a specific study, in a wind tunnel or by digital simulation, exploring all the wind directions in 20° or 30° steps, the most unfavorable directional factor of the directions contained in the sector of ±15° around the direction considered should be used.
In Belgium, you can use the values of {c: In Belgium, you can use the values of {cdir} defined by the table below.
In Metropolitan France, you can use the: In Metropolitan France, you can use the values of {cdir} defined by the map below, provided that the nominal angular sector including the wind directions associated with the pressure or force coefficients used in the calculations, is entirely contained by the interval.

The rotary nature of tropical cyclones w: The rotary nature of tropical cyclones which affect certain Overseas Departments does not allow any reduction for the effect of management in these departments.

Snow zones and wind zones are specified: Snow zones and wind zones are specified on maps provided in the national annexes to the Eurocode 1.
Seism zones are specified on maps provid: Seism zones are specified on maps provided in the national annexes to the Eurocode 8 or in national legal texts.
Each country has set characteristic snow: Each country has set characteristic snow loads on the ground for each portion of its territory.
The division is usually specified in the: The division is usually specified in the national annex of Eurocode 1 part 1-3.
Each country has set fundamental value o: Each country has set fundamental value of the basic wind velocity for each portion of its territory.
The reference velocity corresponds to th: The reference velocity corresponds to the average wind velocity over 10 minutes, measured at 10m above ground level on an 'open country' site with a return period of 50 years.
The division is usually specified in the: The division is usually specified in the national annex of Eurocode 1 part 1-4.
Each country has set reference peak grou: Each country has set reference peak ground acceleration on type A ground for each portion of its territory.
The type A ground has a stratigraphic pr: The type A ground has a stratigraphic profile like rock or other rock-like geological formation, including at most 5m of weaker material at the surface.
The division is usually specified in the: The division is usually specified in the national annex of Eurocode 8 part 1-1.
First, you need to calculate the value o: First, you need to calculate the value of snow on the ground at the relevant site :
depending on the {sz} in which the build: depending on the {sz} in which the building is located, according to the map taken from the national annex to the Eurocode 1 part 1-3.
taking into account the effect of the el: taking into account the effect of the elevation.
Then, you can take into account the annu: Then, you can take into account the annual probability of exceedence by calculating the ground snow load with a return period equivalent to the design working life of your building.
The wind direction is to be considered f: The wind direction is to be considered for several reasons :
First, the high velocities of wind are o: First, the high velocities of wind are observed more frequently in certain direction sectors;
the directional factor accounts for this: the directional factor accounts for this by authorizing a reduction when the wind comes from a direction where the probability of occurrence of strong winds is less.
On the other hand, the orography and the: On the other hand, the orography and the roughness of the terrain generally vary with the direction of the wind.
Finally, the pressure or force coefficie: Finally, the pressure or force coefficients depend on the direction of the wind relative to the construction.
To accurately determine the peak velocit: To accurately determine the peak velocity pressure, you will have to take into account many parameters such as :
the {wz} according to the map taken from: the {wz} according to the map taken from the national annex to the Eurocode 1 part 1-4.
the {apof} by calculating the basic wind: the {apof} by calculating the basic wind velocity {vb} with a return period equivalent to the design working life of your building.
the {rf} {crz}, to take into account the: the {rf} {crz}, to take into account the effect of the environment (vegetation / urbanization).
the {of} {coz}, to take in account the e: the {of} {coz}, to take in account the effect of terrain relief.
Then you can calculate the wind peak vel: Then you can calculate the wind peak velocity pressure:
{qp} is the pressure in newtons per squa: {qp} is the pressure in newtons per square meter ({N_m2}).
{Ivz} is the turbulence intensity, at he: {Ivz} is the turbulence intensity, at height z, defined as the standard deviation of the turbulence divided by the mean wind velocity.
{rho} is the air density in kilogram per: {rho} is the air density in kilogram per cubic meter ({kg_m3}).
v is the velocity in kilometers per hour: v is the velocity in kilometers per hour (km/h).
q is the pressure in newtons per square: q is the pressure in newtons per square meter ({N_m2}).
In cases of very low seismicity, the pro: In cases of very low seismicity, the provisions of Eurocode 8 need not be observed.
It is recommended to consider as very lo: It is recommended to consider as very low seismicity cases either those in which the design ground acceleration on type A ground, {ag}, is not greater than 0.39{ms2}, or those where the product {agS} is not greater than 0.49{ms2}.
The {sz}, the {agr} values and the chose: The {sz}, the {agr} values and the chosen method may be found in national Annexes or in the law specific to each country.

What is the orography factor for ?: What is the orography factor for ?
How to calculate the orography factor ?: How to calculate the orography factor ?
How to get the elevation data ?: How to get the elevation data ?
The wind velocity is different depending: The wind velocity is different depending on whether the building is on a terrain with no slope, a hill or a cliff;
the orography factor is used to model th: the orography factor is used to model the influence of the relief on the {ce}.
The general procedure, given in Eurocode: The general procedure, given in Eurocode 1 part 1-4 §A.3, is applicable for a well individualized obstacle (an emergent zone compared to a general ground without marked relief).
It takes into account the slope of the t: It takes into account the slope of the terrain that the wind follows and the position of the building in relation to the top of the hill or the crest of the escarpment.
The windward terrain can be considered u: The windward terrain can be considered up to a distance of 10 times the height of the isolated orographic element.
When the orography increases wind veloci: When the orography increases wind velocity by more than 5%%, it is recommended to consider the effects using the orography factor {co}.
The effect of orography may be neglected: The effect of orography may be neglected when the average slope of the terrain in the wind is less than 3°.
The French national annex offers an addi: The French national annex offers an additional procedure called « complex orography »:
This is applicable in all circumstances: This is applicable in all circumstances and consists in comparing the altitude of the construction site {Ac} with altitudes {Ai} in several directions at distances of 500m and 1000m:
The orography factor resulting from this: The orography factor resulting from this operation is valid if it is not greater than 1.15, otherwise it is very likely that the building is facing a marked relief falling under the general procedure.
Many solutions (but the last one is real: Many solutions (but the last one is really effective {wink}) :
You can use topographic maps, old fashio: You can use topographic maps, old fashioned!
You can use specialized sites to provide: You can use specialized sites to provide altitudes based on a GPS point like {MD} or software like Google Earth, but it remains tedious when it is necessary to get several altitudes at precise distances.
I advise you rather to try {ECZ} which i: I advise you rather to try {ECZ} which is capable of automatically calculating the orography factor according to the procedure adapted to your case.

When the design working life of a buildi: When the design working life of a building is les or more than 50 years, you have to use the probability factor {cprob} to calculate the basic wind velocity {vb} with a return period equivalent to the design working life of your building.
{vb0} is the {fvbwv} given by the maps i: {vb0} is the {fvbwv} given by the maps in the national annexes.

What is the roughness factor for ?: What is the roughness factor for ?
How to calculate the roughness factor ?: How to calculate the roughness factor ?
The wind velocity is different depending: The wind velocity is different depending on whether the building is on the coastline, in a forest or in a city center;
the roughness factor is used to model th: the roughness factor is used to model the influence of the building environment on the mean wind speed at a given height and on the turbulence intensity.
First of all, the exposure factor method: First of all, the exposure factor method is only valid for a height up to {zmax};
beyond this height, the effect of the wi: beyond this height, the effect of the wind must be specifically studied.
The terrain factor {kr} only depend of t: The terrain factor {kr} only depend of the roughness length {z0} :
is the roughness length for the terrain: is the roughness length for the terrain category II.
The roughness factor {cr} at a given hei: The roughness factor {cr} at a given height z only depend of the roughness length {z0} but with the limitation {rule} :
The Eurocode provides five terrain categ: The Eurocode provides five terrain categories with which values are associated:
is the roughness length in meters corres: is the roughness length in meters corresponding to the height at which the theoretical wind speed would become zero.
is the minimum height in meters correspo: is the minimum height in meters corresponding to the threshold below which the pressure no longer reduces.
Sea, coastal area exposed to the open se: Sea, coastal area exposed to the open sea
Lakes or area with negligible vegetation: Lakes or area with negligible vegetation and without obstacles
Area with low vegetation such as grass a: Area with low vegetation such as grass and isolated obstacles (trees, buildings) with separations of at least 20 obstacle heights
Area with regular cover of vegetation or: Area with regular cover of vegetation or buildings or with isolated obstacles with separations of maximum 20 obstacle heights (such as villages, suburban terrain, permanent forest)
Area in which at least 15%% of the surfa: Area in which at least 15%% of the surface is covered with buildings and their average height exceeds 15m
These terrain categories, the values ass: These terrain categories, the values associated with them and the distance over which they are evaluated can be adapted for each country in their respective national annexes.
The terrain categories must be observed: The terrain categories must be observed for each wind direction.
For a building with a rectangular base,: For a building with a rectangular base, the surrounding space can for example be divided into 4 sectors of 90° (-45° to + 45° compared to normal to the walls of the building).
Eurocode 1 part 1-4 indicates that the t: Eurocode 1 part 1-4 indicates that the terrain must be observed at an angle of 30°, for each of the angular sectors of 90° it will therefore be necessary to observe the category of terrain on a slippery portion of 30°.
The lowest roughness length within any 3: The lowest roughness length within any 30° angular wind sector should be used and small areas (less than 10%% of the area under consideration) with deviating roughness may be ignored.

What are the Belgian seismic zones accor: What are the Belgian seismic zones according to Eurocode 8 ?
In Belgium, the division is specified in: In Belgium, the division is specified in the national annex to Eurocode 8 (The map below was created from this data).
The Belgian area is divided into five se: The Belgian area is divided into five seismic zones identified from 0 to 4.
In Belgian regulations, the zones consid: In Belgian regulations, the zones considered to be zones with very low seismicity are the zones for which the product {agS} (with {ag}) does not exceed 0.06g (0.59{ms2}).
The soil factor S is depending of the st: The soil factor S is depending of the stratigraphic profile of the ground and the type of recommended elastic response spectra with respect to the surface-wave magnitude.
Rock or other rock-like geological forma: Rock or other rock-like geological formation, including at most 5m of weaker material at the surface.
Deposits of very dense sand, gravel, or: Deposits of very dense sand, gravel, or very stiff clay, at least several tens of metres in thickness, characterised by a gradual increase of mechanical properties with depth.
Deep deposits of dense or medium-dense s: Deep deposits of dense or medium-dense sand, gravel or stiff clay with thickness from several tens to many hundreds of metres.
Deposits of loose-to-medium cohesionless: Deposits of loose-to-medium cohesionless soil (with or without some soft cohesive layers), or of predominantly soft-to-firm cohesive soil.
A soil profile consisting of a surface a: A soil profile consisting of a surface alluvium layer with Vs values of type C or D and thickness varying between about 5m and 20m, underlain by stiffer material with Vs>800m/s.
Buildings are classified in 4 importance: Buildings are classified in 4 importance classes, depending on the consequences of collapse for human life, on their importance for public safety and civil protection in the immediate post-earthquake period, and on the social and economic consequences of collapse.
Each importance class is attached to an: Each importance class is attached to an importance factor {gI}.
Buildings of minor importance for public: Buildings of minor importance for public safety, e.g. agricultural buildings, etc.
Ordinary buildings, not belonging in the: Ordinary buildings, not belonging in the other categories.
Buildings whose seismic resistance is of: Buildings whose seismic resistance is of importance in view of the consequences associated with a collapse, e.g. schools, assembly halls, cultural institutions etc.
Buildings whose integrity during earthqu: Buildings whose integrity during earthquakes is of vital importance for civil protection, e.g. hospitals, fire stations, power plants, etc.
NOTE: Importance classes I, II and III o: NOTE: Importance classes I, II and III or IV correspond roughly to consequences classes CC1, CC2 and CC3, respectively, defined in the Annex B to Eurocode 0.

These are the European standards applica: These are the European standards applicable to {structural_calculations} of buildings.
They contribute to the development of th: They contribute to the development of the construction sector in Europe and some countries of Africa.
They provide a common language for all u: They provide a common language for all users and simplify software development.
From 2010, National Standards have been: From 2010, National Standards have been withdrawn and are no longer maintained.
Eurocodes became mandatory for the speci: Eurocodes became mandatory for the specification of European public works.
In the private sector, it is also the re: In the private sector, it is also the reference standard for claims expertise by insurance companies.
There are ten codes in 60 parts (you can: There are ten codes in 60 parts (you can find the whole list a bit further below).
Each of them is accompanied by National: Each of them is accompanied by National Annexes for the 28 user countries (Austria, Belgium, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Iceland, Ireland, Italy, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Spain, Slovakia, Slovenia, Sweden, Switzerland and United Kingdom).
The structural calculations according to: The structural calculations according to the {eurocodes} are the verifications of the resistance, equilibrium and deformation of a building by a mathematical calculation based on the basis of indications from European construction standards.
The calculations take into account the a: The calculations take into account the actions applied to the building (arising from occupancy, climatic, seismic, fire, ...), the characteristics of the foundation soil, the materials used to make the structure (concrete, steel, wood, aluminum, ...) and the reliability objectives to be achieved (which is not the same for a hospital as for a warehouse).
These calculations can be complex and mu: These calculations can be complex and must be carried out as part of a structure design process by a competent person, the {structural_engineer}.
Any new building, extension or rehabilit: Any new building, extension or rehabilitation will require structural checks by calculation.
These calculations make it possible to c: These calculations make it possible to choose the right construction components and the appropriate size to ensure the stability, solidity and sufficient rigidity of the structure.
If the project is located at altitude, t: If the project is located at altitude, the snow load can be high.
By the seaside, on a hill or in open ter: By the seaside, on a hill or in open terrain, the wind can be more powerful.
In some areas, the structure of the buil: In some areas, the structure of the building could also be subject to seismic effects.
It is also often necessary to ensure tha: It is also often necessary to ensure that the structure is able to resist a fire for a sufficient time to evacuate and that the firefighters can intervene.
It is therefore important to carry out s: It is therefore important to carry out structural calculations to anticipate exceptional phenomena and prove the design of the building in the event of a disaster.
It is difficult to give a generic price,: It is difficult to give a generic price, the costs vary according to the size of the project and its complexity.
The price is based on the time the engin: The price is based on the time the engineer estimates or the number of elements to calculate.
In general, the cost of a structural eng: In general, the cost of a structural engineer is largely paid for by the savings made by optimizing the volume of materials and the design so that it is easier to manufacture and assemble.
In addition, his insurance covers damage: In addition, his insurance covers damage in the event of a claim due to a design error and serenity is priceless.

Simple unweighted load case - rounded in: Simple unweighted load case - rounded in daN

The diagram of the normal forces circula: The diagram of the normal forces circulating in the roof plane is provided in the calculation report {button_service}.
The top flange is restrained by the purl: The top flange is restrained by the purlins.
The purlins will be linked to the nodes: The purlins will be linked to the nodes of the roof cross-bracing.
So the lateral-buckling length of the to: So the lateral-buckling length of the top flange is the distance between purlins.
The lower flange is restrained plumb wit: The lower flange is restrained plumb with the column (torsional restraint) and the diagonal braces (torsion spring), so lateral-buckling is checked between these points without considering the influence of warping restraint at the supports.
Lateral-buckling of the lower flange is: Lateral-buckling of the lower flange is checked for a double length in the cantilevered parts located after the diagonal braces.
Flexural buckling about y-y axis is calc: Flexural buckling about y-y axis is calculated for a cantilever column with 2 nodal forces of varying intensities (the first at the top and the second at the intersection with the diagonal brace).
For each force distribution (depending o: For each force distribution (depending on the load combination), this buckling length therefore varies within an interval between 2 times the level of diagonal brace intersection and 2 times the total height of the column.
Longitudinal stability is provided by a: Longitudinal stability is provided by a St. Andrew's cross, so flexural buckling about z-z axis is calculated for a column with one fixed end and one pinned end.
Flexural buckling about y-y and z-z axis: Flexural buckling about y-y and z-z axis are calculated for a cantilever column with 2 nodal forces of varying intensities (the first at the top and the second at the intersection with the diagonal brace).
For each force distribution (depending o: For each force distribution (depending on the load combination), these buckling lengths therefore vary within an interval between 2 times the level of diagonal brace intersection and 2 times the total height of the column.
No vehicle impact on the columns is take: No vehicle impact on the columns is taken into account in this analysis.
If the risk is acceptable, it is not nec: If the risk is acceptable, it is not necessary to take special measures.
Otherwise, risk mitigation measures are: Otherwise, risk mitigation measures are to be planned (signage / protection / additional structural analysis in an accident situation).
The connecting bolts of the steel parts: The connecting bolts of the steel parts will be of the SB type (Structural Bolt) and class 8.8 minimum.
Drillings will comply with standard EN 1: Drillings will comply with standard EN 1090-2 §6.6.1 « Dimensions of holes ».
The rotation of the column base is block: The rotation of the column base is blocked around the X and Y axes at {cb_level}m level on {cc} concrete foundation blocks.
The anchorages consist of threaded rods: The anchorages consist of threaded rods each fitted with an anchor pad bolted to its end embedded in the concrete.
The positioning jig plate is useful for: The positioning jig plate is useful for positioning anchors when pouring concrete and for obtaining a flat contact surface.
A central hole 50 mm in diameter will be: A central hole 50 mm in diameter will be provided to serve as a vent during the pouring of the concrete.
The column base plate can be lengthened: The column base plate can be lengthened and widened to eventually make oversized holes (the distance from the axis of the hole to the edge of the column base plate must be at least 1.5 times the diameter of the hole).
In this case, to allow the transfer of t: In this case, to allow the transfer of the shear force from the column base plate to the anchor bolts, it will be necessary to (several solutions to choose from):
Weld the top pads to the column base pla: Weld the top pads to the column base plate.
Fill the annular space (with a suitable: Fill the annular space (with a suitable anchoring resin for example).
Add 1 anchor peg on either side of the c: Add 1 anchor peg on either side of the column in normal holes (direct take-up of shear by the anchor pegs).
If normal holes are provided, these addi: If normal holes are provided, these additional provisions are not necessary.
Supplementary reinforcement of concrete: Supplementary reinforcement of concrete to avoid cone failure
The rafter is bolted to the column via a: The rafter is bolted to the column via an end plate made of S235 steel.
This connection is calculated as a pin.
The diagonal braces gussets will be made: The diagonal braces gussets will be made of minimum {grade} steel.
On the rafter/column side, the connectio: On the rafter/column side, the connection consists of a single gussets welded to the flange on both sides along its length (2 welding fillets per gusset) and centered on the web.
On the brace side, the connection consis: On the brace side, the connection consists of a single centered gusset welded on an end plate and forming a T.
This T are welded at the ends of the dia: This T are welded at the ends of the diagonal braces around its perimeter.
The gussets are connected to each other: The gussets are connected to each other by two bolts (and hardened washers) functionning in simple shearing.
This connection system causes an eccentr: This connection system causes an eccentricity of the forces which pass through the diagonal brace from the other elements and, consequently, creates an out-of-plane moment in the diagonal brace.
A lateral stiffener is therefore provide: A lateral stiffener is therefore provided to prevent the the gussets centered on the diagonal braces and their welds from being stressed by out-of-plane bending.
On the brace side, the connection consis: On the brace side, the connection consists of two gussets forming a fork into which the single gusset fits.
The fork is made up of the two external: The fork is made up of the two external gussets between which a metal furring strip is welded to form an assembly.
This assembly is inserted into a shaped: This assembly is inserted into a shaped groove at the ends of the diagonal braces and then welded around its perimeter.
Dimensions of the metal furring strip:: Dimensions of the metal furring strip:
Length = Depth of the shaped groove in d: Length = Depth of the shaped groove in diagonal brace,
Width = Width of diagonal brace + 10 mm,: Width = Width of diagonal brace + 10 mm,
Thickness = Thickness of the internal gu: Thickness = Thickness of the internal gusset + clearance with the external gussets.
The external and internal gussets are co: The external and internal gussets are connected to each other by two bolts functionning in double shearing and in bending (due to the clearance between the gussets useful for assembly).
The roof plane is stiffened by installin: The roof plane is stiffened by installing an angle (cross) truss in the plane of the slope.
The angles are linked together and on th: The angles are linked together and on the rafters by gussets.
The central gusset of each cross is fixe: The central gusset of each cross is fixed on the intermediate purlins.
These gussets are connected to the brace: These gussets are connected to the braces by several class 8.8 bolts functionning in simple shearing.
A St Andrew's Cross made of angles is in: A St Andrew's Cross made of angles is installed to limit the buckling length of the columns about the z-z axis and their longitudinal deformation.
The angles are linked together and on th: The angles are linked together and on the columns by gussets.
These gussets are connected to the angle: These gussets are connected to the angles of the cross by several class 8.8 bolts functionning in simple shearing.

Automatic design of the column anchorage: Automatic design of the column anchorage on the concrete foundation and generation of the associated sketches.
